http://schema.org/medicineSystem.description: The system of medicine that includes this MedicalEntity, for example 'evidence-based', 'homeopathic', 'chiropractic', etc.

http://schema.org/potentialAction.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

http://schema.org/description.description: A short description of the item.

http://schema.org/relevantSpecialty.description: If applicable, a medical specialty in which this entity is relevant.

http://schema.org/recognizingAuthority.description: If applicable, the organization that officially recognizes this entity as part of its endorsed system of medicine.

http://schema.org/mainEntityOfPage.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described. See background notes for details. Inverse property: mainEntity.

http://schema.org/study.description: A medical study or trial related to this entity.

http://schema.org/image.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

http://schema.org/code.description: A medical code for the entity, taken from a controlled vocabulary or ontology such as ICD-9, DiseasesDB, MeSH, SNOMED-CT, RxNorm, etc.

http://schema.org/additionalType.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

http://schema.org/guideline.description: A medical guideline related to this entity.

http://schema.org/sameAs.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

http://schema.org/image.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

http://schema.org/medicineSystem.description: The system of medicine that includes this MedicalEntity, for example 'evidence-based', 'homeopathic', 'chiropractic', etc.

http://schema.org/study.description: A medical study or trial related to this entity.

http://schema.org/potentialAction.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

http://schema.org/expectedPrognosis.description: The likely outcome in either the short term or long term of the medical condition.

http://schema.org/pathophysiology.description: Changes in the normal mechanical, physical, and biochemical functions that are associated with this activity or condition.

http://schema.org/signOrSymptom.description: A sign or symptom of this condition. Signs are objective or physically observable manifestations of the medical condition while symptoms are the subjective experience of the medical condition.

http://schema.org/stage.description: The stage of the condition, if applicable.

http://schema.org/primaryPrevention.description: A preventative therapy used to prevent an initial occurrence of the medical condition, such as vaccination.

http://schema.org/code.description: A medical code for the entity, taken from a controlled vocabulary or ontology such as ICD-9, DiseasesDB, MeSH, SNOMED-CT, RxNorm, etc.

http://schema.org/cause.description: An underlying cause. More specifically, one of the causative agent(s) that are most directly responsible for the pathophysiologic process that eventually results in the occurrence.

http://schema.org/guideline.description: A medical guideline related to this entity.

http://schema.org/additionalType.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

http://schema.org/sameAs.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

http://schema.org/possibleTreatment.description: A possible treatment to address this condition, sign or symptom.

http://schema.org/naturalProgression.description: The expected progression of the condition if it is not treated and allowed to progress naturally.

http://schema.org/riskFactor.description: A modifiable or non-modifiable factor that increases the risk of a patient contracting this condition, e.g. age, coexisting condition.

http://schema.org/description.description: A short description of the item.

http://schema.org/relevantSpecialty.description: If applicable, a medical specialty in which this entity is relevant.

http://schema.org/possibleComplication.description: A possible unexpected and unfavorable evolution of a medical condition. Complications may include worsening of the signs or symptoms of the disease, extension of the condition to other organ systems, etc.

http://schema.org/subtype.description: A more specific type of the condition, where applicable, for example 'Type 1 Diabetes', 'Type 2 Diabetes', or 'Gestational Diabetes' for Diabetes.

http://schema.org/epidemiology.description: The characteristics of associated patients, such as age, gender, race etc.

http://schema.org/associatedAnatomy.description: The anatomy of the underlying organ system or structures associated with this entity.

http://schema.org/recognizingAuthority.description: If applicable, the organization that officially recognizes this entity as part of its endorsed system of medicine.

http://schema.org/mainEntityOfPage.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described. See background notes for details. Inverse property: mainEntity.

http://schema.org/typicalTest.description: A medical test typically performed given this condition.

http://schema.org/secondaryPrevention.description: A preventative therapy used to prevent reoccurrence of the medical condition after an initial episode of the condition.

http://schema.org/differentialDiagnosis.description: One of a set of differential diagnoses for the condition. Specifically, a closely-related or competing diagnosis typically considered later in the cognitive process whereby this medical condition is distinguished from others most likely responsible for a similar collection of signs and symptoms to reach the most parsimonious diagnosis or diagnoses in a patient.

This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

http://schema.org/sameAs.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

description: Any condition of the human body that affects the normal functioning of a person, whether physically or mentally. Includes diseases, injuries, disabilities, disorders, syndromes, etc.

http://schema.org/healthCondition.description: Expectations for health conditions of target audience.

http://schema.org/diagnosis.description: One or more alternative conditions considered in the differential diagnosis process.

http://schema.org/usedToDiagnose.description: A condition the test is used to diagnose.

http://schema.org/relatedCondition.description: A medical condition associated with this anatomy.

title: MedicalCondition
